Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The evolution of hair and fur: Proximate and ultimate mechanisms shaping primate pelage variation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines how core physiological and evolutionary processes shape biological diversity. Elucidating how genetic changes and selection pressures result in trait variation is a central goal of biology, and key to this is identifying the links between genes, form and function, and how these can alter the fitness of individuals and the evolutionary success of species. Moreover, understanding why and how many cellular and body structures have evolved independently in different species can explain how evolution takes multiple routes to 'solve' the same problem.

The biology of hair is an ideal system for studying these links between genetics, form and function. Hair is an anatomical trait that is shaped by both natural selection (e.g., providing camouflage against predators, protection from parasites, maintaining body temperature in cold environments) and sexual selection (e.g., signaling sex, age, status). It is a universal characteristic of mammals, yet across species there is striking variation in the color, pattern, growth, and texture of hair. Moreover, many hair traits, such as tail stripes or thick woolly coats, seem to have evolved repeatedly in different mammal lineages. Hair also is a trait for which small genetic differences can have major phenotypic effects; for example, red hair in humans is due to variation at a single gene.

This project applies cutting-edge genomic and comparative analyses to understand how genetic variation and selection have shaped this important anatomical feature (hair) in humans and other primates. In so doing, it also will provide a critical evolutionary context to understand one of the biological traits that make humans unique (relative hairlessness). Through conduct of the research, several undergraduate and graduate students, including individuals recruited from groups underrepresented in science, as well as a postdoctoral scholar, will receive extensive and broad scientific training. In addition, because many human and animal diseases are associated with hair changes and loss, this project is relevant for aspects of public health and dermatological and clinical research on hair/skin conditions. Animal hair also is an important commercial product; identifying the biological factors that shape hair characteristics in natural-living species could eventually improve the yield and quality of hair-based products. And finally, the project will generate a wealth of genetic and metric data on primate diversity that will contribute to research in conservation and evolutionary biology, as well as furthering research in biological anthropology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project focused on understanding the evolution of hair diversity in primates. We generated a comprehensive dataset consisting of several hair characteristics (hair length, thickness, and density) from 366 museum skins, which represented 96 primate species. This dataset contained more than 45,000 measurements. These data will be used in several analyses, including the examination of sex differences in hair characteristics, the relationship between hair traits and parasites, and the correlation between climate variation and primate hair anatomy. We have also used our dataset to investigate how primate hair color is seen from the perspective of different animals (including primate predators) with different types of color vision. Also, we have started to examine some of these questions on a finer scale, establishing field-based studies of living lemurs in Madagascar. At the genetic level, we are investigating how gene expression is associated with different hair characteristics within and across owl monkey species. We have presented some of our initial findings at national and regional academic conferences.

Our project has provided numerous training and research opportunities to both undergraduate and graduate students. Fifteen undergraduate students, most from underrepresented populations in STEM, have participated as research assistants on the project, gaining knowledge and experience in database creation, data organization, lab techniques, and image analysis. In addition, three graduate students have worked on the project, with two students using the museum dataset for their dissertation research. Finally, a postdoctoral research scientist working on the project is now a tenure-track assistant professor and she has expanded a component of this project for her own research on the genetic basis of beard characteristics in men. We have disseminated our work to the public via science outreach programs in the Amherst, MA and Washington, D.C. areas. In addition, we have hosted public science events for school-aged kids in our labs. The final project museum and genomic data will be available through publically-available databases.

We are currently pursuing new avenues to connect our research to “real-world” problems. We have established a new collaboration with the US Fish and Wildlife Forensics Lab to use our hair trait database to aid animal identification in wildlife crimes cases.
